questions.text: 1. A 12-year-old child with chronic kidney disease (CKD) presents with bowing of legs. He also had minimal sun exposure. Laboratory investigations reveal Serum Calcium: 7 mg/dL, Serum Phosphate: 6.9 mg/dL (elevated), Alkaline Phosphatase: 370 mg/dl (elevated), and low 25(OH) Vitamin D levels. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
In this case, the most appropriate management is calcium and vitamin D supplementation.

The child with CKD has hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, low vitamin D levels, and clinical signs of renal rickets such as bowing of the legs. The primary problem is reduced activation of vitamin D by the diseased kidneys, which leads to poor calcium absorption and secondary hyperparathyroidism. Supplementing with calcium directly corrects the hypocalcemia, while giving active forms of vitamin D (calcitriol/alfacalcidol) improves intestinal calcium absorption, suppresses parathyroid overactivity, and helps in bone mineralisation. Together, calcium and vitamin D address the core abnormalities driving the bone disease in CKD.

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) refers to kidney damage that persists for at least three months, involving structural or functional abnormalities of the kidneys, which may occur with or without a reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Disturbances in calcium and phosphate metabolism, impaired renal production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, chronic acidosis, and secondary hyperparathyroidism can lead to bone complications, collectively known as CKD-mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD). Factors such as poor appetite, malnutrition, and skeletal abnormalities also contribute to impaired growth.

At the initial stage, management focuses on ensuring adequate nutrition and slowing the progression of kidney failure. Although the kidneys can regulate potassium levels until the later stages, their ability to quickly excrete a potassium load is diminished, so foods high in potassium should be limited. Calcium supplementation is typically provided as calcium carbonate or calcium acetate. Phosphate consumption is reduced by limiting the intake of dairy products. Phosphate binders are given if the patient is not responding to dietary restriction of phosphate (Options A and C). Supplementation with vitamins such as thiamine, riboflavin, folic acid, pyridoxine, and B12, along with vitamin D, is also recommended.

As the disease advances, addressing complications becomes necessary, and kidney replacement therapy, including hemodialysis or transplantation, may then be required (Option D).

questions.text: 2. A neonate was screened and was found to have congenital hypothyroidism. T3 and T4 levels were decreased, and there was no radioactive tracer uptake but thyroid gland was normal on USG. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause is defect in iodine transport.

The neonate has low T3 and T4, a structurally normal thyroid gland on ultrasound, but no radioactive tracer uptake. For radioactive iodine to be taken up by the thyroid, the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) must transport iodine into the gland. If this transport mechanism is defective, the thyroid gland will appear normal anatomically but will not concentrate iodine, leading to absent tracer uptake and hypothyroidism.

The steps of synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones are shown below:



Other options:

Option A: Iodine deficiency is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism worldwide, and maternal iodine intake is critical during pregnancy for fetal thyroid function. However, in iodine deficiency, the thyroid gland typically increases its trapping activity, so tracer uptake would be high rather than absent.

Option C: In thyroid agenesis, the thyroid is absent and the ultrasound would not show a normal gland. Since the gland is present, this is ruled out. Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism. In one-third of cases of dysgenesis, no thyroid tissue is present, known as thyroid agenesis.

Option D: Dyshormonogenesis refers to defects in hormone synthesis after iodine is already taken up. Because increased TSH stimulation has a trophic effect on thyroid follicular cells, a goiter is often present. In such cases, the tracer uptake is usually increased, not absent, because the gland tries to compensate.

questions.text: 3. An unusually tall 14-year-old boy with extremely long limbs came to the opthalmologist with complaints of diminution of vision. On examination, there was bilateral subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis). Which of the following defects is found in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marfan's syndrome and the likely protein involved in this condition is fibrillin 1.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15.

It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. Ghent criteria is used for diagnosing Marfan syndrome.  The main features are tall stature, ectopia lentis and aortic root dilatation. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

* Tall stature and long limbs 

* Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum

* Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)

* Scoliosis

Cardiovascular manifestations:

* Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 

* Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm

* Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

* Ectopia lentis with upward and outward displacement of the lenses due to weakening of the ciliary zonules

* Myopia with blurred vision

* Retinal detachments

* Early cataracts and glaucoma

The image below shows ectopia lentis in marfan syndrome:



Other options:

Option B: COL5A/2 is mutated in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, presents with hyperextensible skin and joint laxity.

Option C: LDLR gene is involved in familial hypercholesterolemia, leading to high LDL and xanthomas.

Option D: PLOD1 gene causes a rare form of Ehlers-Danlos (kyphoscoliotic type) with scoliosis and fragile tissue.

questions.text: 4. A primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation was diagnosed as HIV-positive, for which ART was initiated. She had a viral load of 1200 copies/mL. The baby of 2.5 kg was delivered at term through vaginal delivery and baby was healthy. What is the next step as per our setup?

choices.text: Syp Nevirapine plus Zidovudine for 12 weeks with exclusive breastfeeding
Start Nevirapine prophylaxis schedule of 6 weeks and exclusive breast feeding
Single dose nevirapine to be given and do exclusive breast feeding
Stop breastfeeding and start formula feeds

questions.solution:
This scenario depicts a high-risk infant for HIV, and prophylaxis with Nevirapine with Zidovudine for 12 weeks with exclusive breastfeeding should be started immediately.

This is considered a high-risk infant because the mother was diagnosed with HIV only at 34 weeks of gestation, meaning Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) was started late and there was inadequate time for full viral suppression. At the time of delivery, her viral load was high at 1200 copies/mL, which is more than 1000 copies/mL, which increases the risk of vertical transmission. Hence, prophylaxis with Nevirapine with Zidovudine for 12 weeks with exclusive breastfeeding should be started immediately.

Immediate postnatal ART prophylaxis is crucial in reducing HIV transmission risk and improving long-term health outcomes in exposed infants. Mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV is the primary route of pediatric HIV infection, occurring during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding. 

For ART prophylaxis, a single drug or dual drug regimen is followed, depending on the risk of transmission, which can be low or high risk.

* Low-risk infants are those born to mothers with a low viral load (<1000 copies/mL) which is detected after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery. 

* High-risk infants are those born to HIV-positive mothers, not on ART, with viral load not estimated beyond 32 weeks, maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks (>1000 copies/mL), or mothers newly diagnosed with HIV within 6 weeks of delivery.

HIV Risk ART prophylaxis Duration
Low-risk infants

Syrup Nevirapine or Syrup Zidovudine (in situations where Nevirapine will not be effective)

 Birth to 6 weeks of age, irrespective of feeding 
High-risk infants Dual prophylaxis with Syrup Nevirapine plus Syrup Zidovudine

In case of:

  • Exclusive replacement feeding: Birth to 6 weeks
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: Birth till 12 weeks 


Exclusive breastfeeding (EBF) is recommended for all HIV-exposed infants. At 6 months of age, these infants should be offered complementary foods along with breast milk.

Risk Factors for MTCT: 

* High maternal viral load

* Advanced maternal HIV disease or primary infection during pregnancy

* Rupture of membranes for more than four hours

* No maternal ART use

* Chorioamnionitis or placenta previa

Diagnosis in infants under 18 months requires HIV DNA/RNA PCR testing at 6 weeks using a dried blood spot test. If positive, confirmation is needed with a second whole blood test. Antibody tests are unreliable before 18 months due to passive maternal antibody transfer.

According to the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO), antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be given to all pregnant women, including during labor hours and breastfeeding. They are started on a triple-drug ART. ART should be given irrespective of the CD4 count, and clinical stage and should be continued lifelong.



Pearl PM2199: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

* HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.

* Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.

* Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers

* Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)

* Exclusive breastfeeding counseling

* Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby

* Initiation of ARV in babies:

* Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age

* High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)

* Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women

* Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: 5. A newborn presents with deformity in all four limbs, and there was no index finger in the right hand. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is amniotic band syndrome, as the absence of the index finger along with limb deformities is characteristic of constrictive amniotic bands disrupting normal development. 

Disruptions are caused by destruction of a previously normally formed body part. One mechanism is entanglement and tearing apart or amputation of a normally developed structure by strands of amnion within amniotic fluid called as amniotic bands. This sporadic congenital anomaly is known as amniotic band syndrome. The other mechanism is interruption of blood supply causing infarction, necrosis, and resorption of structures distal to the insult. If interruption occurs early, absence of a body part may result. 

Other options:

Option A: CTEV is an isolated deformity of the foot and does not involve absent fingers or all four limbs, so it cannot explain the presentation.

Option C: Cerebral palsy is a neurological disorder causing abnormal tone and movement. It does not cause congenital structural malformations or missing digits, so it’s not the likely diagnosis.

Option D: Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita causes multiple joint contractures at birth involving all four limbs, but digits are present. Absence of the index finger rules this out.

questions.text: 6. A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with fever and seizures. What is the most appropriate immediate treatment for this child?
questions.solution:
Diazepam is the most appropriate immediate treatment for this child.

Diazepam is a benzodiazepine, a class of drugs primarily used as sedatives and anti-anxiety agents, but they also have antiseizure properties. In this case of febrile seizures, diazepam acts by increasing the frequency of openings of GABA-activated chloride channels, making neurons less excitable and helping stop seizure activity. It has a well-defined role in the management of seizures because it works quickly to suppress the spread of convulsions and reduce high-frequency neuronal firing.

questions.text: 7. A mother is feeding her 7-month-old baby thick homemade cereal as supplementary feeds besides breastfeeding. What is the volume and frequency of feeds most appropriate for this baby in a period of 24 hours based on the Infant and Young Child Feeding guidelines (IYCF)?
questions.solution:
½ –1 katori 3 times a day, along with frequent breastfeeding is the most appropriate for this 7-month-old baby in a period of 24 hours based on the Infant and Young Child Feeding guidelines (IYCF).

The quantity of complementary food to be offered as per the Infant and Young Child Feeding guidelines (IYCF) is given below:

Age Frequency Amount at each meal
6 months 2 times per day plus frequent breastfeeds 2-3 tablespoons
7-8 months 3 times per day plus frequent breastfeeds Increasing gradually to 2/3 of a 250 ml katori/ bowl (which is roughly stated as 1/2 to 1 katori)
9-11 months 3 meals plus 1 snack between meals plus breastfeeds 3/4 of a 250 ml katori/ bowl
12-24 months 3 meals plus 2 snacks between meals plus breastfeeds A full 250 ml katori/ bowl or more
